According to current models the inhibitory capacity of <extra_id_0> I(kappa)B(alpha) <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> would be mediated through the retention of Rel / NF-kappaB proteins in the cytosol .

text: To gain better insight into the potential role of nuclear <extra_id_0> I(kappa)B(alpha) <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in a physiological context we have analysed its presence in the nucleus of human peripheral blood T lymphocytes ( PBL ) .

We demonstrate the nuclear localization of <extra_id_0> I(kappa)B(alpha) <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in PBL by different techniques : Western blot , indirect immunofluorescence and electron microscopy .
Low levels of nuclear <extra_id_0> I(kappa)B(alpha) <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> were detected in resting cells whereas a superinduction was obtained after PMA activation .

text: Unexpectedly , the presence of nuclear <extra_id_0> I(kappa)B(alpha) <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> did not inhibit NF-kappaB binding to DNA and this phenomenon was not due to the presence of <extra_id_0> IkappaBbeta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> at the nuclear level .

text: Immunoprecipitation experiments failed to demonstrate an association between nuclear <extra_id_0> I(kappa)B(alpha) <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and NF-kappaB proteins .

Our results demonstrate that in resting and PMA - activated human PBL , <extra_id_0> I(kappa)B(alpha) <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is present in the nucleus in an apparently inactive form unable to disrupt NF-kappaB binding from DNA .
